column1: Thrush is a yeast infection of the tongue and mouth.
Thrush occurs when too much of a yeast called Candida albicans grows in a baby's mouth.
Thrush often occurs when mother or baby has taken antibiotics.
Babies can also get a yeast infection on the diaper area at the same time.
The yeast gets in the baby's stool and can cause a diaper rash.

Symptoms of thrush in the baby include: - White, velvety sores in the mouth and on the tongue - Wiping the sores may cause bleeding - Redness in the mouth - Diaper rash - Mood changes - Refusing to nurse because of soreness Some babies may not feel anything at all.
Symptoms of thrush in the mother include: - Deep-pink, cracked, and sore nipples - Tenderness and pain during and after nursing
Your pediatrician can usually diagnose thrush by looking at your baby's mouth and tongue.
Your pediatrician may prescribe antifungal medicine to treat thrush.
If you have a yeast infection on your nipples, your doctor may recommend an over-the-counter or prescription antifungal cream.
If both you and your baby have the infection, you both need to be treated at the same time.
Call your doctor if: - Your baby has symptoms of thrush - Your baby refuses to eat - You have symptoms of a yeast infection on your nipples
